results.title: Carter Williams, Who Unshackled Nursing Home Residents, Dies at 97
results.abstract: By closely describing the inner lives of older people, Ms. Williams altered legal regulations and clinical standards applied to nursing homes.

multimedia.caption: Carter Catlett Williams in 2014. Her advocacy played a key role in the passage of the Nursing Home Reform Act.
Carter Catlett Williams in 2014. Her advocacy played a key role in the passage of the Nursing Home Reform Act.

results.title: Parents Face Murder Charge in Death of Girl With Severe Lice
results.abstract: Some experts were skeptical that lice alone could have killed the girl, Kaitlyn Yozviak. The case underscored fears about how the pandemic has cut children off from people who could report neglect.

results.title: Instead of Reassurance, Trump’s Doctor Delivers Confusion, Experts Say
results.abstract: Dr. Sean P. Conley, who admitted that he had misled the public about the president’s treatment, has lost credibility with some colleagues.
org_facet: Reed, Walter, National Military Medical Center

multimedia.caption: Dr. Sean P. Conley speaking to reporters on Sunday. He has ducked and sidestepped questions about the president’s condition.

results.title: Can Halloween Be Saved? Yes, Experts Say. Here’s How.
results.abstract: You can still safely celebrate the ghoulish season, but trick-or-treating and other celebrations may have to be modified to protect against coronavirus infection.

multimedia.caption: It’s important that children be allowed to enjoy spooky festivities this year because “holidays like Halloween mean a lot to kids,” one expert said.

results.title: Identify the Different Symptoms of the Flu and Covid-19
results.abstract: With fears of a “twindemic” in the United States this fall, here’s a guide to understanding what’s making you feel terrible.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

results.title: For Trump, the Only Medical News Is Good Medical News
results.abstract: Conflicting accounts of the president’s condition underline the fact that the public does not have a definitive answer about the president’s health.
org_facet: Reed, Walter, National Military Medical Center

multimedia.caption: In comments to reporters, Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff, offered a grimmer assessment of the president’s condition that stood in stark contrast to the optimistic prognosis his doctors issued minutes earlier.

results.title: Trump’s Covid Treatments Are Aimed at Preventing Severe Illness
results.abstract: Outside experts pointed to the therapies as signs that the president’s health may not be as good as his doctors said. His age, weight and gender put him at high risk.
results.byline: By Gina Kolata and Apoorva Mandavilli
org_facet: Reed, Walter, National Military Medical Center

multimedia.caption: Dr. Sean P. Conley, the White House physician, offered few details about the president’s condition outside Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., on Saturday.

results.title: 74 and Overweight, Trump Faces Extra Risks From ‘a Very Sneaky Virus’
results.abstract: The president has boasted of his health and is sure to receive the best possible care, but he carries a number of risk factors as he begins his battle with Covid-19.

multimedia.caption: President Trump has access to unusual treatments like an experimental antibody cocktail, but he faces risk factors including his age, weight and sex that put him in a higher-risk group for a severe infection.

President Trump has access to unusual treatments like an experimental antibody cocktail, but he faces risk factors including his age, weight and sex that put him in a higher-risk group for a severe infection.

results.title: Joan Marks, Doyenne of Genetic Counselors, Dies at 91
results.abstract: She taught counselors to empower their patients to make informed medical decisions about genetic tests and inherited diseases.

multimedia.caption: Joan Marks, standing, teaching a human genetics class in the 1980s at Sarah Lawrence College, where she headed the nation’s first genetic counseling program.

results.title: President Trump Received Experimental Antibody Treatment
results.abstract: Mr. Trump received a single dose of an antibody cocktail made by the biotech company Regeneron. The company’s C.E.O. has known the president for years.

results.title: Trump Has the Coronavirus. What Risks Does He Face?

results.title: After Wildfires Stop Burning, a Danger in the Drinking Water
results.abstract: Experts are warning that existing water safety rules are not suitable to a world where wildfires destroy more residential areas than in the past.

results.abstract: The fund that covers thousands of performers will require that they work more weeks per year to qualify.

results.title: Renée C. Fox, Founding Figure of Medical Sociology, Dies at 92
results.abstract: She is credited with helping to create the field of bioethics and applying the methods of sociology to medical care.

results.title: Why Male Baboons Benefit From Female Friends
results.abstract: These male monkeys lived longer if they socialized with females, with or without benefits.
org_facet: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B (Journal)

results.title: Where You Carry Body Fat May Affect How Long You Live
results.abstract: Extra weight in some places may lower your risk of dying prematurely.

results.title: China’s ‘Golden Week’ Kicks Off in Boost to Battered Tourism Industry
results.abstract: Chinese travelers are expected to fan out across the country in droves, even as anxiety about the virus and the economy lingers.

multimedia.caption: Tourists waiting to enter the Forbidden City in Beijing on Thursday. It was the first day of a weeklong holiday that may offer the clearest measure yet of China’s recovery from the pandemic.

results.title: Laughter May Be Effective Medicine for These Trying Times
results.abstract: Doctors, nurses and therapists have a prescription for helping all of us to get through these difficult times: Try a little laughter.

results.title: Timothy Ray Brown, First Patient Cured of H.I.V., Dies at 54
results.abstract: Known initially as the “Berlin Patient,” he underwent an experimental stem cell transplant 13 years ago that rid his body of the virus. He died of leukemia.

multimedia.caption: Timothy Ray Brown, the first person cured of H.I.V., in 2019. In 2007, he received a bone marrow transplant from a donor who was immune to H.I.V.

results.abstract: The C.D.C. director wanted a “no sail” order extended until February, a policy that would have upset the tourism industry in the crucial swing state of Florida.

results.title: She Craved Salt and Felt Nauseated for Months. What Was Wrong?
results.abstract: She was always tired, and her stomach had become strangely fragile. But her unaccountably tan skin clued doctors in to what ailed her.

results.title: Cats Shed More Than Dogs. The Coronavirus, Not Fur.
results.abstract: A new experiment confirmed that cats can spread the virus to one another, and found dogs did not shed the virus. There’s still no evidence that pets transmit it to humans.
org_facet: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

multimedia.caption: A new study shows that cats are capable of transmitting the coronavirus to other cats.

results.title: ‘Testing Hell’: Gift of Devices to Nursing Homes Brings New Problems
results.abstract: The federal government sent free rapid-test machines to 14,000 facilities. But they have come with unexpected costs, cumbersome reporting rules and questions about accuracy.
org_facet: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
